item.title: China Likely to Challenge U.S. Supremacy in East Asia, Report Says
item.description: But the report, by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said American-Chinese interdependence would prevent China from trying to force the United States out.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: A Chinese commander adjusts the cap of a soldier in Beijing, ahead of a visit by President Fran√ßois Hollande of France in April.

item.title: China Cracks Down on Military LIcense Plates
item.description: Officials are cracking down on the abuse of privileges that come with a military license plate, in a bid to address public anger at the army.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Chinese navy officers pose for photographs with the new, left, and old military car license plates in Hebei Province.

item.title: Besieged Syrian Leader, Bashar al-Assad, Makes Rare Appearance
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad‚Äôs visit to a power plant in the capital, Damascus, came after consecutive days of deadly bombings in the heart of his power base.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: In a photo released by the Syrian official news agency, SANA, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, center, visited a Damascus power plant on Wednesday.

item.title: Greeks Stage General Strike Against Austerity
item.description: The Greek protest came as workers around the world observed the international Labor Day with demonstrations and rallies. News reports said most went off quietly.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A nationwide general strike on Wednesday to protest government austerity measures in Greece was called by the country‚Äôs two main labor unions.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In Amsterdam, the Golden Age of Museum Renovation
item.description: Just in time for coronation week, the Van Gogh Museum, the Rijksmuseum and the Stedelijk are all finally open again.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Vincent van Gogh's "Self-portrait," from 1887-1888, is on view at the newly reopened museum that bears his name.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 1
item.description: International Labor Day observed in India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A rickshaw puller in Kolkata, West Bengal, carrying a passenger on a hand-pulled rickshaw, on International Labor Day, also known as International Workers' Day. ¬†

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Dying Long Distance
item.description: One of the consequences of an expatriate life is separation from family and friends, and from the major life events that define families. How do you deal with the loss of a loved one when you‚Äôre on the other side of an ocean?
item.dc:creator: By JAN BENZEL

item.title: Roadside Bomb Kills 3 British Soldiers in Afghanistan
item.description: In other violence in Helmand Province, an Afghan government peace negotiator and two of his bodyguards were killed in an ambush, according to news reports.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In New Chinese Campaign, Concerns Over Morals and Corruption
item.description: With corruption and abuse of power rife in China, a new government campaign appears to be telling 80 million Communist Party members, ‚ÄúClean up your act or else,‚Äù But how effective will it be?
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, right, with President Fran√ßois Hollande of France, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing last month.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Psychiatrist Dinesh Bhugra, Expert on Deviant Sexual Behavior
item.description: A psychiatrist on what drives certain people to sexually assault children.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE

item.title: Letter from China: Allegiance, the Privilege of the Party
item.description: Politics in China are often viewed through the prism of party politics. But something far older and more powerful is at play: an ancient moral code of fidelity to a lord, or fealty.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Low-Cost Indonesian Airlines Keep Growing, Despite Troubling Record
item.description: The recent crash of a Lion Air flight off Bali last month came as the carrier ordered 234 planes for $24 billion, its second major expansion deal in three years.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: National Rescue Team, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescuers at the crash site of a Lion Air plane off the Indonesian resort island of Bali last month.

item.title: China Data Confirm Slowdown in Factories
item.description: An official index showed a drop in growth for April, mirroring a report from the British bank HSBC.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: The Female Factor: The Face of the Gay Rights Movement
item.description: High-profile men have tightened their hold on the leadership as strategists, promoters, spokesmen and financiers.
item.dc:creator: By LUISITA LOPEZ TORREGROSA

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Echoes of Saddam‚Äôs War in Dilemma Over Syria‚Äôs Chemical Weapons
item.description: Western leaders want proof before taking action on Syria‚Äôs alleged use of chemical weapons. In an earlier conflict, they had the proof but did nothing.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: A Kurdish woman at a monument for the dead in Halabja.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Extinction Nears for China‚Äôs ‚ÄòRiver Pig,‚Äô the Finless Porpoise
item.description: Six years ago the Baiji dolphin was declared functionally extinct in China‚Äôs Yangtze River. Its close relative, the finless porpoise, may die out in 10 years, conservationists say.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Urgent conservation work is needed if the finless porpoise, which lives in the Yangtze River, is not to die out like the Baiji dolphin did six years ago, says the WWF.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 1
item.description: Arrest in Bangladesh; Obama recommits to closing Guant√°namo; cash in China; Berlin names streets for women; and Oslo runs out of trash.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers escorting Sohel Rana, owner of the building that collapsed in Bangladesh last week, into court on Monday.

item.title: India Ink: Lawyer to Contest Congress Leader Sajjan Kumar‚Äôs Acquittal in 1984 Riots Case
item.description: After more than two decades of pursuing the case in court and several acquittals, lawyer for victim of riots says he won‚Äôt quit.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Congress party leader Sajjan Kumar in New Delhi on Aug. 9, 2005.

item.title: India Ink: 4-Year-Old Rape Victim Dies in India
item.description: A 4-year-old girl who was raped and dumped near a crematorium in central India died on Monday evening from cardiac arrest, hospital authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA and MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Chinese Cruise to Disputed Paracel Islands Angers Vietnam
item.description: In a move China calls ‚Äútourism‚Äù but others have likened more to ‚Äúimperialism‚Äù, a first Chinese cruise ship is currently touring the Paracel Islands, claimed by China, Vietnam and Taiwan, Chinese media reported.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screengrab from the Internet of a Liaoning Satellite TV report on the first Chinese cruise to the Paracel Islands, showing what appears to be Yongxing Island, Woody Island in English and Phu Lam Island in Vietnamese, with its landing strip.

item.title: Lens Blog: Brendan Bannon's Photos of Horse Racing in Kenya
item.description: Despite the dirty, difficult daily labor, the empty stands and the low pay, Kenya‚Äôs hardy horse racing community is deeply committed to keeping the sport alive.
item.dc:creator: By MIKE PFLANZ

item.title: Push to Include Gay Couples in Immigration Bill
item.description: Republican sponsors of the immigration bill say that an amendment to allow immigrants in long-term same-sex relationships to obtain green cards would sink the entire measure.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:credit: Ben Garvin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ness, left, and Ginger Madeiros with their 8-month-old son, Jamie, at home in Minneapolis. Ness is in the United States on a temporary visa.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Cuba: U.S. Allows President‚Äôs Daughter to Travel
item.description: The State Department will allow President Ra√∫l Castro‚Äôs daughter to travel to Philadelphia to receive a gay civil rights award.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Court Bars Musharraf From Office for Life
item.description: A Pakistani court on Tuesday barred Pervez Musharraf, the country‚Äôs former military ruler, from running for public office for life.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Deadly Anti-Muslim Violence Flares Up
item.description: Buddhist mobs overran a pair of mosques and set hundreds of homes ablaze in central Myanmar on Tuesday, wounding at least 10 people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
